(c)  At the time a motor vehicle is stopped to give the notice described in this section, and at the time a motor vehicle is stopped after the giving of such notice, and prior to issuing a citation to the operator of the motor vehicle, the officer shall afford the operator or a passenger in the motor vehicle an opportunity to explain his or her conduct. No person shall be convicted for violating section 31-78 if it appears at trial that the explanation given was true and disclosed a lawful purpose, and that the lawful purpose did not constitute unnecessary repetitive driving. Refusal by the person to explain his or her conduct to the officer shall not be deemed an element of the offense or evidence establishing probable cause that the person has violated this section, nor shall such refusal be admissible against the person in a trial of the offense. 
(Ord. No. 7560, 4-5-93) 
Sec. 31-80. - Exclusions. 
    Section 31-78 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any public service, police, fire, emergency, or other governmental vehicle or any ambulance when operated in official capacity; or 
(2)  Any licensed public transportation vehicle or any vehicle utilized for business or commercial purposes, when operated for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 7560, 4-5-93) 
Sec. 31-81. - Designation of streets. 
    The city manager, the chief of police, or the ranking police officer on duty in the police department is authorized to designate a public street, other than a state highway, as a designated or "cruising restricted" street upon a determination that a state of congested traffic, as defined in section 31-77, exists. Such designation shall include any portion of the street within which the congested traffic condition is found to exist. Upon the designation of a public street as a designated or "cruising restricted" street, the police department shall post or cause to be posted notices to the public to such effect, and shall establish one (1) or more traffic control points to identify the vehicles being operated upon the designated street. 
(Ord. No. 7560, 4-5-93) 
Sec. 31-82. - Penalty 
    Any person violating section 31-78 shall, upon conviction, be subject to the imposition of a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 7560, 4-5-93) 
Chapter 32 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; garbage and refuse, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, adopted Feb. 6, 2012, effective Feb. 29, 2012, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, §§ 32-1-32-12, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1955, §§ 25-1, 25-2, 25-4; Ord. No. 7134, § 3, adopted Sept. 21, 1981; Ord. No. 7410, § 1, adopted April 3, 1989. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The term "city" as used in this chapter shall mean the City of Jacksonville Beach, or where appropriate the term shall also mean the city manager, to include the manager's assigned representative(s), who is responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter of the City Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  The term "delinquent date" as used in this chapter shall mean the day following the due date. 
(c)  The term "disconnect date" (termination date) as used in this chapter shall mean the service disconnection day. 
(d)  The term "due date" as used in this chapter shall mean the 21st day after the billing date. 
(e)  The term "electric system" as used in this chapter shall mean and be deemed to include all poles, wires, transmission lines, fixtures, transformers, attachments, equipment and other facilities owned and used by the city in the production and distribution of electric power, and all equipment and property used in connection therewith and all other facilities of any nature or description, real or personal, now or later owned or used by the city in the production and distribution of electric power by its municipally owned electric system. 
(f)  The term "sewer system" as used in this chapter shall mean and be deemed to include all conduits and works operated by the city for the collection and conveying of sanitary sewage from the pipe connection at the property line in the street fronting the individual properties to the point of final disposition, and all equipment and facilities used in connection therewith, including all pipelines, manholes, trunk lines, pumping equipment, lift stations, purification and treatment facilities and works whatsoever, real or personal, now or later owned or used by the city in the operation of the sewer system. 
(g)  The term "utilities" as used in this chapter shall mean those services rendered by the city (i.e., electric, natural gas, water, sewer, stormwater, solid waste, reclaimed water and other services as may be added or modified from time to time by the city.) 
(h)  The term "utility account" as used in this chapter shall mean a numbered record of debit and credit entries to cover transactions pertaining to the billing of utilities. 
(i)  The term "water system" as used in this chapter shall mean and be deemed to include all wells, pumping stations, purification plants and other sources of supply of water and all pipes, mains and other parts of the facilities for the distribution of water, and all equipment and property used in connection therewith and all other facilities of any nature or description, real or personal, now or later owned or used by the city in the supply and distribution of water by its municipally owned water system. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-2. - [Reserved.] 
Sec. 32-3. - General utility charges and fees. 
    Schedule of charges and fees. General utilities charges and fees shall be established, described, and adjusted by resolution from time to time and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Late charges and delinquency reconnect charges. 
(2)  Deposits. 
(3)  Cut-in service charges. 
(4)  Service charges for tampering with utility service. 
(5)  Service charges for meter tests. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-4. - Application required for utility service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use city utilities without first making written application for service, before the service is desired, and paying all costs, charges, fees and deposits incident thereto. Signed applications shall be made on forms furnished by the city and shall constitute an agreement by the applicant with the city to abide by all provisions of this chapter and the city's applicable rules relating to its utility services rendered as may from time to time be operative and effective. Applications for utility service shall be accompanied by positive identification, i.e., a valid driver's license. Applications for service by firms, partnerships, associations and corporations shall be tendered only by their authorized agents, and the official title of the parties shall be signed to the application. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-5. - Withholding or discontinuing service authorized when indebtedness to city not paid. 
    The city may withhold or discontinue service rendered under application made by any member or agent of a family, household, organization or business unless all prior indebtedness to the city of the family, household, organization or business for service has been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-6. - Recovery of delinquent charges. 
    The city may recover by due process of law the amount of any unpaid utility service charge, including but not limited to, all billed charges and amounts, collection costs, applicable interest charges, attorney fees, and delinquency fees. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-7. - Payment of charges, delinquent accounts, late charges and reconnect charges. 
(a)  Bills for service will be rendered monthly, but the rendering of bills is not an obligation on the part of the city, and failure of the consumer to receive the bill(s) shall not release or diminish the consumer's obligation to pay any bill, or relieve the consumer of any obligation under this chapter. 
(b)  All bills including service charges and taxes are due and payable at the utility billing office when rendered to the consumer; however, if payment in full has not been received in the utility billing office by 5:00 p.m. on or before the due date that shall be twenty-one (21) days after the bill is rendered, then the bill shall be deemed delinquent and all bills incur a late charge. Immediately upon a bill becoming delinquent, the finance officer or his designee shall notify the consumer by written notice that the bill is delinquent and that unless the delinquent bill is paid before the disconnection date on the notice, the city shall have the delinquent services discontinued until the bill or bills for all billed service(s) previously rendered to the customer, together with any applicable service charges, has been paid. Applicable service charges may be applied for, but not be limited to, the following services: 
(1)  Customer request for reconnecting service. 
(2)  Field collection of bills and service charges for a delinquent account without being disconnected 
(c)  In order to accommodate customers on social security, on disability income or with extraordinary hardship circumstances that are determined to be a reasonable basis for accommodation by the city's authorized representative, the due date may be altered. 
(d)  The late charge may be waived not more than once per calendar year when it appears that the customer has made a reasonable effort to deliver the payment in a timely manner, that payment was late due to circumstances beyond the control of the customer, and customer has established good payment history. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-8. - Deposits required for service. 
    In case of all applications for utility services, the city shall require payment of all applicable service connection charges and also a deposit in the amount provided below, to secure the payment of bills for utility service as they mature. The deposit shall be held by the city until final settlement of the user's account for utility services furnished by the city, and upon final settlement of the user's account, any unused balance of the deposit will be refunded. All deposits shall be evidenced by nontransferable receipts issued by the city in the name of the prospective consumer applying for service. 
    After a cash deposit has remained with the city for at least six (6) months, it shall then earn simple interest of not more than six (6) percent per annum. Earned interest shall be paid at the time that the deposit is refunded. 
(1)  Deposit schedule. All deposit amounts are subject to review and adjustment based upon average monthly utility bills when service is changed, becomes delinquent or is disconnected for nonpayment. A one-time review of deposits will be made upon request after the first six (6) months of service to determine if the deposit amount should be decreased. 
(2)  Deposit types: 
a.  Residential. 
b.  Commercial, general service and general service demand. 
(3)  Methods of deposit. 
a.  Cash. 
b.  Irrevocable letter of credit. 
c.  Indemnity bond. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-8.1. - Waiver of residential deposits. 
    Residential deposits may be waived if the consumer accompanies his application for utility service with a letter of credit, in a format approved by the city, from a previous utility which states that the customer has received utility service for a minimum of one (1) year and that no charges have been made against the account in the past twelve (12) months for: 
(1)  Late payments; 
(2)  Delinquent disconnection; 
(3)  Dishonored checks; 
(4)  Meter tampering. 
    A residential deposit may be required to be reinstated if, at any later date, the account payment history contains late payments, delinquent disconnections, dishonored checks, and or meter tampering, or if there is a change in service provided, or a change of service locations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-9. - Refund of deposits. 
(a)  Residential deposits will be refunded after a minimum of one (1) year of service at the same service address, provided that no charges have been made against the account in the past twelve (12) months for: 
(1)  Late fees; 
(2)  Delinquent cut-off fees; 
(3)  Dishonored checks: 
(4)  Meter tampering. 
(b)  Commercial, general service and general service demand deposits are not refundable before termination of service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-10. - Cut-in service charges. 
    A service charge for the cut-in of new, transferred, or renewed utility service shall be paid in accordance with established charges as set by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-11. - Basis of billing when meter inoperative. 
    If any meter on the user's premises is destroyed by fire or other cause, or fails to register, the user will be billed for the period involved on a basis of previous consumption. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-12. - Tampering with utility service. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way meddle, tamper with or otherwise alter or change the utility system on any premises, or to in any way interfere with a meter or meter connection. And should it appear that any utility services have been received by meddling or tampering, then and in that event the city shall have the right to discontinue the service until the defect is corrected. The consumer or property owner may be charged with and billed for the utility service as provided by F.S. § 812.14 or as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  The following charges for the repair or replacement of equipment damaged due to meddling or tampering with a utility service shall be set by resolution and include but are not limited to: 
(1)  To remove or lock meter for unauthorized consumption, cost to replace damaged equipment and estimated cost of kWh consumption. 
(2)  To remove meter or lock for unauthorized consumption, cost to replace damaged equipment, estimated cost of kWh consumption and disconnection of overhead or underground service cable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-13. - Testing of meters; payment of costs; special readings. 
    Upon written notice, a meter will be tested by the city and in the event the meter, when tested, is found to be not more than two (2) percent fast, the expense of the test shall be paid by the consumer. Otherwise, the expense of the test will be borne by the city and billing adjustments for a period not to exceed six (6) months will be made. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Secs. 32-14, 32-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 2, adopted Feb. 6, 2012, effective Feb. 29, 2012, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 32-16-32-35, 32-41-32-53, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1955, §§ 25-26-25-43; Ord. No. 7016, § 1, adopted Oct. 1, 1979; Ord. No. 7376, § 1, adopted April 4, 1988; Ord. No. 2009-7973, § 1, adopted August 3, 2009. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference- Water and sewers in trailer camps, § 17-30; sanitation regulations in trailer camps, § 17-33. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-16. - Designated essential public utilities; compulsory connection required where available. 
(a)  The use of the city's water system and sewer system including improvements, replacements, extensions or additions as may from time to time be added thereto, or incorporated therein, are determined and declared to be essential for the protection and preservation of the public health, comfort, safety, economy and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(b)  The owner, tenant or occupant of each lot or parcel of land within the city, which abuts a street, alley, easement or other public way, containing a city water or sewer main, or which is located within one hundred (100) feet of a city water or sewer main, and upon which lot or parcel a building or other inhabitable structure has been or shall be erected for residential, commercial or industrial use, shall be required to connect the building or structure to the water and sewer systems or to as many of the several and respective systems as may from time to time be extended so as to be or become available within the above distance within three hundred sixty-five (365) days after notification that the system is available, and shall thereafter refrain from using, or cease to use, any other method for utility services which are now, or may later become available; and shall thereafter pay all the charges, fees and rates as provided for and set by resolution. All connections shall be in accordance with city rules and regulations which shall be established from time to time, which may provide for reasonable charges set by resolution. 
(c)  The owner, tenant, occupant, user or consumer shall pay all established water and sewer rates, charges and fees for the capacity and use of water from the city's water system and for the capacity and disposal of wastewater to the city's sewer system, except as set forth otherwise within this article. 
(d)  In the areas in the city limits, outside of the limits or distance as specified in subsection (b) from the sewer lines, and where water is available for flushing, no outdoor toilets shall be permitted and every dwelling or other occupied structure shall be provided with a sanitary septic tank. 
(e)  The same rules applicable to the installation of plumbing in the city shall apply to the installation of septic tanks and the same fees for inspection as are provided in this code for plumbing inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-17. - Water meter installation; ownership and cost. 
    Except for charges specified in Article I and Article II, the city will install and properly maintain at its own expense meters and piping necessary for meter installation as may be necessary to measure the water service used by the consumer. All meters and meter piping and meter box or meter vault installed by or for the city shall remain the city's property. It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate any city owned appurtenances on water service(s). The consumer shall properly protect the city's property on the consumer's property or on city properties adjacent to consumer's property, and in the event of any loss or damage to the city's property caused by or arising out of carelessness, neglect or misuse by the customer, or other unauthorized parties, the cost of making good the loss or repairing the damage, shall be paid by the consumer or property owner. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-18. - Water service lateral piping and sewer service lateral piping; responsibility. 
(a)  The property owner or consumer is responsible for the water service lateral piping from the premises' facilities to the adjacent city right-of-way or to the connection with the city's water main, whichever is applicable. 
(b)  The property owner or consumer is responsible for the sewer service lateral piping from the premises' facilities to the adjacent city right-of-way or to the connection with the city's sewer main, whichever is applicable. 
(c)  It shall be the property owner's or consumer's responsibility to ensure that the water service lateral piping and the sewer service lateral piping are compliant with all applicable codes, regulations and laws as maybe enacted from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-19. - Determination of type of water or sewer service. 
(a)  There shall be no free services rendered by the city's water or sewer systems. 
(b)  The city manager, or the manager's authorized representative, shall have the authority to determine what type of water or sewer service shall be rendered by the city in the case of any and all service applications, and shall have continuing authority to, at all times, require charges that may be appropriate to bring each service into conformity with sound municipal practice or as otherwise provided by law. (c) Water service for irrigation only or primarily irrigation purposes shall not be established except as set forth otherwise within this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-20. - Water and sewer rates, charges and fees. 
    Schedule of rates, charges and fees. The schedule of rates, charges and fees for the water and sewer systems utility shall be established, described and adjusted by resolution from time to time and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Water rate charges. The water rates for monthly charges for water services and facilities provided by the city's water system are based on water meter measurement, water meter size and fire protection service lateral. 
a.  Base water rate. The rate shall be applicable to the meter size through which retail quantities of water are delivered to the consumer and shall be rendered monthly to each consumer, in addition to the volume rate. The resulting full fixed base water rate charge shall be paid by the consumer, whether or not the volume water rate charge may be for a fractional part of month as may be involved in the start or stop of service. 
b.  Volume water rate. The rate shall be applicable to all retail quantities of water shown by monthly meter readings, or fractional part as may be involved in the start or stop of service, to have been delivered to the consumer. The resulting volume water rate charge shall be paid by the consumer. 
c.  Fire protection service water rate. The rate shall be applicable to all water service laterals (water tap) provided exclusively for sprinkling systems or other fire protection systems in buildings or on premises and shall be rendered monthly as either a single charge or pro rated equally to the consumer(s) within the buildings or premises. The resulting full fixed fire protection service water rate charge shall be paid by the consumer(s) to which it is rendered, whether or not the volume water rate charge may be for a fractional part of month as may be involved in the start or stop of service. 
(2)  Sewer rate charges. The sewer rates for monthly charges for sewer services and facilities provided by the city's sewer system are based on water meter measurement and water meter size. 
a.  Base sewer rate. The rate shall be applicable to the meter size through which retail quantities of water are delivered to the consumer and shall be rendered monthly to each consumer, in addition to the volume rate. The resulting full fixed base sewer rate charge shall be paid by the consumer, whether or not the volume sewer rate charge may be for a fractional part of month as may be involved in the start or stop of service. 
b.  Volume sewer rate. The rate shall be applicable to all retail quantities of water shown by monthly meter readings, or fractional part as may be involved in the start or stop of service, to have been delivered to the consumer. The resulting volume sewer rate charge shall be paid by the consumer. 
(3)  Water service charges. 
a.  Water installation charge. The charge is based on meter size and shall be paid by the consumer for the city to furnish and install water service lateral from water main to the property line, for install events that consist of new lateral, change of lateral size or change of a lateral location. 
b.  Water meter charge. The charge is based on meter size and shall be paid by the consumer for the city to furnish and install water meter and meter piping and meter box, for install events that consist of new meter, change of meter size and change of meter location. 
c.  Water capital improvement charge. The charge is based on either meter size or type facility for multiple living units and shall be paid by the consumer to the city, for install events that consist of new lateral, change of lateral size and change of lateral location. Water capital improvement charges paid to the city shall be deposited and held in a special account designated as the "The Water and Sewer Capital Improvement Account." The moneys deposited and held in the account shall be used for the improvements, expansion and/or replacement of the water, sewer and reclaimed systems, to include, but not limited to, the water treatment and wastewater treatment facilities. Unencumbered monies shall be carried over from year to year in this account. 
(4)  Sewer service charges. 
a.  Sewer installation charge. The charge is based on sewer service lateral size (sewer tap) and shall be paid by consumer for the city to furnish and install the sewer service lateral from the sewer main to the property line, for install events that consist of new lateral, change of lateral size or change of lateral location. 
b.  Sewer capital improvement charge. The charge is based on either meter size or type facility for multiple living units and shall be paid by the consumer to the city, for install events that consist of new lateral, change of lateral size and change of lateral location. Sewer capital improvement charges paid to the city shall be deposited and held in a special account designated as the "The Water and Sewer Capital Improvement Account." The moneys deposited and held in this fund shall be used for the improvements, expansion and/or replacement of the water, sewer and reclaimed systems, to include, but not limited to, the water treatment and wastewater treatment facilities. Unencumbered monies shall be carried over from year to year in this account. 
(5)  Other charges for water and sewer services. 
a.  Temporary water service charges. Temporary water service for circuses, fairs, carnivals, jetting, construction work and the like, shall be rendered upon written application accompanied by the advance payment of the amounts the city may determine sufficient to cover the city's estimated cost of furnishing a suitable meter for measuring and gauging the water furnished through the requested connection, together with materials, labor and other expense to be incurred by the city in providing extensions or facilities for rendering service. Users shall pay the city for all quantities of water shown by monthly, or other specified meter readings, to have been delivered through connections at the same schedule of rates as set forth in this article. Upon termination of this service, any balance of this deposit shall be refunded to the user. 
b.  Additional burden sewer rate charge. The monthly sewer rate charge may be increased (but in no event decreased) according to rates and charges as may be established and adjusted from time to time as being fair and equitable after investigation to determine whether the quantity, character, or strength of sewage or industrial waste from any source or premises imposes a burden upon the city's sewer system greater than the burden imposed by the average domestic sewage entering the city's sewer system, in which event increased rates or additional charges shall be made in an amount that the city shall deem to be fair and equitable to meet the additional cost of collection, treatment and disposal of sewage or industrial waste; and the city may, if it deems advisable, compel the owner, tenant or occupant of the building or premises to treat the sewage or industrial waste in the manner that the city shall specify before discharging the sewage into the city's sewer system. 
c.  Cross-connection control fee. All new construction, rehabilitation and/or remodeling will require cross-connection control devices and the owner or consumer shall pay associated fees as established and described and as adjusted from time to time. 
d.  Other charges or fees, that are established and described, and as adjusted from time to time, by the city, related to providing water and sewer services to consumers, operating and maintaining the water and sewer systems, and to implementing all related regulations and policies. 
(6)  Water supplied to the city. 
a.  The cost for the city of taking water from the city's water system through its fire hydrants for the prevention and extinguishment of fire and for flushing streets and other municipal needs shall be incorporated into the established schedule of rates and charges to be paid by all other consumers. 
b.  All other water services and all sewer services used by the city for municipal purposes shall be paid for according to the established schedule of applicable rates and charges. 
c.  The city shall use alternative water supplies for municipal irrigation purposes where practical. When not practical and water from the city's water system is used, the city shall pay all applicable established water rates and charges. 
d.  Revenues received for water and sewer services furnished to the city shall be deemed to be revenues derived from the operation of the city's water and sewer systems utility and shall be applied and accounted for in the same manner as other revenues derived from the operation of the systems; provided that nothing in this chapter shall be construed as requiring the city to avail itself of the facilities or services afforded by the utility. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Secs. 32-21-32-25. - Reserved. 
Sec. 32-26. - User's liability for water and sewer service; duration. 
    Liability for water or sewer service shall respectively begin on the day the user is connected to the city's water or sewer main in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall continue unless disconnected for nonpayment or other cause, until a request is given to the city by the user to terminate the service. No allowance will be made for vacant houses unless a request to have the water and sewer service shut off is received by the city, nor will any allowance be made for any shutoff period less than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-27. - Obstructing or leaking water service pipe or sewer service pipe, responsibility of keeping clean, in good repair and watertight. 
(a)  Water service pipe. 
(1)  The owner, tenant or occupant of the property shall be continuously responsible for maintaining and keeping the water pipe leading to and between the plumbing system of his premises to the city's main water line clean and free from obstruction, and shall not cause, suffer or permit any article or thing to be introduced into the pipe which causes a stoppage, including tuberculation of the pipe. Failure to keep the water pipe leading from the plumbing system to the water main clean and maintained in proper condition will give the city the right to cut off the water connection, which shall not be reconnected until the water pipe is cleaned and maintained properly. 
(2)  The owner, tenant or occupant of the property shall be continuously responsible for maintaining and keeping the water pipes leading to and between the plumbing system of his premises to the city's main water line in good repair and watertight so as to prevent the loss of water from the water system and to prevent the introduction of any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to the water system. Failure to keep the water pipe leading from the plumbing system to the water main in good repair and watertight will give the city the right to cut off the water connection until the water pipe is repaired and watertight. 
(b)  Sewer service pipe. 
(1)  The owner, tenant or occupant of the property shall be continuously responsible for maintaining and keeping the sewer pipe leading to and between the plumbing system of his premises to the city's main sewer line clean and free from obstruction, and shall not cause, suffer or permit any article or thing to be introduced into the pipe which causes a stoppage. Failure to keep the sewer pipe leading from the plumbing system to the sewer main clean and maintained in proper condition will give the city the right to cut off the water connection, which shall not be reconnected until the sewer pipe is cleaned and maintained properly. 
(2)  The owner, tenant or occupant of the property shall be continuously responsible for maintaining and keeping the sewer pipes leading to and between the plumbing system of his premises to the city's main sewer line in good repair and watertight so as to prevent the introduction of any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to the sanitary sewer. Failure to keep the sewer pipe leading from the plumbing system to the sewer main in good repair and watertight will give the city the right to cut off the water connection until the sewer pipe is repaired and watertight. 
(c)  City reserves authority to work on water service lateral piping and sewer service lateral piping. In the best interests of the safety and health of the public, the city may clean, repair, maintain and/or bring into code compliance water service lateral piping or sewer service lateral piping, where these pipes are on city land or rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-28. - Leaks. 
(a)  No allowance or adjustment of any volume of water delivered shall be made for leaks of any nature occurring on the consumer's side of the meter. An allowance or adjustment of a water bill may be made to the extent that any water usage in excess of the normal monthly usage due to a leak on the consumer's side of the meter based upon the time of year and prior consumption history may be adjusted to the rate in effect for zero (0) to four (4,000) gallons. The city shall decide the extent of an allowance or adjustment based upon prior consumption history. Any request for adjustment must be accompanied by documentation of the leak, in a format acceptable to the city. 
(b)  Also, an allowance or adjustment of a volume billed for excess sewer may be made if the water service was broken at a point where the discharge did not enter the sanitary sewer system. The city shall decide the extent of an allowance or adjustment based upon prior consumption history. Any request for adjustment must be accompanied by documentation of the leak, in a format acceptable to the city. No allowances shall be made for running water due to weather conditions. 
(c)  A one-time allowance or adjustment of volume billed for sewer usage may be made to fill swimming pools when newly constructed or when drained for repairs and refilled. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-29. - Right of access to consumer's premises. 
    The applicant shall grant or cause to be granted to the city without cost, all rights, easements, permits and privileges which are necessary for the rendering of water or sewer service. Authorized city employees with proper identification shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of the applicant for the purposes including, but not limited to, reading meters, installing or removing any of its property, examining pipes or fixtures, or for any purpose incidental to the rendering of water and sewer service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-30. - Tapping water and sewer mains, etc., by authorized persons only. 
    No person, except those persons employed or authorized by the city, shall tap the city's water or sewer mains or make any other connection to pipes on the supply side of any meter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-31. - Unauthorized connections. 
    No person shall connect to, or turn on, any water or sewer service, or cut in, interconnect, tap, or make any alteration to any main or distribution or collection pipe of the city's water or sewer system, or in any way interfere with or molest any of the walls, reservoirs, basins or water in the same, or permit any connection or tapping to be made to the city's water or sewer system on his premises or the premises occupied by him, or to knowingly use city water or sewer service from connections in violation of any of the provisions of this article, or any rules or regulations adopted by the city council with respect thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-32. - Connections to be approved by plumbing inspector. 
    No water or sewer service shall be connected until the plumbing and connections incident thereto shall have been inspected and approved by the city plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-33. - City's liability for damages. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damage resulting from consumption, use or exposure to wastewater and/or its possible ancillary bacteriological agents, bursting of any water or sewer main, service pipe or cock, or by shutting off the water, or by discontinuing the operation of its sewage collection, treatment and disposal facilities, for repairs, extensions or connections, or from the accidental failure of the water supply or sewage collection, treatment and disposal system from any cause whatsoever. In cases of emergency the city shall have the right to restrict the use of water or its sewage collection, treatment and disposal system in any reasonable manner for the protection of the city and its water or sewage systems. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-34. - Defining and regulating cross-connections and backflow prevention device assemblies, and providing for corrections. 
(a)  "Cross-connection" means any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected, directly or indirectly with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, lawn sprinklers, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixtures, appliances, or other devices which contain or may contain contaminated water, sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as the result of backflow. By-pass arrangements, connections, removable sections, swivel or changeable devices and other temporary or permanent devices through which or because of which backflow could occur are considered to be cross-connections. All primary (potable use) commercial water services require an approved reduced pressure device assembly. All secondary commercial water services (fire suppression, irrigation, etc.) require an approved backflow prevention device. The type of device assembly required for each secondary service is dictated by the service's degree of hazard as determined in the most current edition of the Manual of Cross-Connection Control published by the Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research at the University of Southern California. 
(b)  No consumer of water from the city water system shall have a cross-connection or potential cross-connection either inside or outside of any building or buildings without an approved backflow prevention device being installed to prevent any and all backflow. All backflow prevention device assemblies are required to be kept in good working order and be field-testable. All backflow prevention device assemblies shall, as a minimum, be tested annually by a certified tester approved by the city. The owner/consumer is responsible for the testing and all maintenance, and the costs. 
(c)  Only the following are considered to be field-testable, backflow prevention device assemblies and shall be installed in agreement with and under supervision of the director of public works or his/her designated representative: 
(1)  Air gap separation is a physical separation between the free flowing discharge end of a potable water supply pipeline and an open or non-pressure receiving vessel. This gap must be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe measured vertically above the rim of the vessel and in no case less than one inch. 
(2)  Reduced pressure device assembly is a device containing within its structure a minimum of two (2) independently acting, approved check valves, with an automatically operating pressure differential relief valve located between the two (2) check valves that will discharge to the atmosphere if the check valves should fail. This unit shall include tightly closing shut-off valves located at each end of the device and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. 
(3)  Atmospheric vacuum breaker is a device operated by atmospheric pressure in combination with the force of gravity. The unit is designed to work on a vertical plane only. The one moving part consists of a poppet valve which must be carefully sized to the slide in a guided chamber and effectively shut off the reverse flow of water when there is a negative pressure. 
(4)  Pressure vacuum breaker is a device similar to an atmospheric vacuum breaker except that the checking unit "poppet valve" is activated by a spring and does not require a negative pressure to react. 
(5)  Double check valve device assembly is an assembly composed of two (2) single, independently acting drip tight check valves, including tightly closing shut-off valves at each end and suitable connections for testing the water tightness of each check valve. 
(d)  The city or its representatives with proper identification may enter at any time inside or outside of any building or buildings for the purpose of checking for cross-connections. If a cross-connection or potential cross-connection is found, the city shall have the right to discontinue water services until the problem has been corrected by elimination or until a proper backflow prevention device has been installed. All backflow prevention devices are subject to periodic inspection by a city representative at city discretion to insure proper operation. 
(e)  These provisions relative to cross-connection have been established for the protection of all the inhabitants of the city and to comply with Chapter 62-555.330 and 62-555.360, Florida Administrative Code or as otherwise provided by law. 
(f)  All water services, plumbing fixtures, and cross-connection control methods shall conform to the cross-connection control standards and procedures as approved by the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-35. - Regulation of landscape irrigation for water conservation. 
(a)  Intent and purpose. It is the intent and purpose of this section to implement procedures that promote water conservation through more efficient landscape irrigation. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. 
(1)  "Address" means the house number of a physical location of a specific property. This includes "rural route" numbers but excludes post office box numbers. If a lot number in a mobile home park or similar community is used by the U.S. Postal Service to determine a delivery location, the lot number shall be the property's address. An "even numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 or the letters A-M. An "odd numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 or the letters N-Z. 
(2)  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
(3)  "Landscape irrigation" means the outside watering of plants in a landscape such as shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens and other flora that are situated in diverse locations such as residential areas, public, commercial, and industrial establishments, and public medians and rights-of-way. Landscape irrigation does not include agricultural crops, nursery plants, cemeteries, golf course greens, tees, fairways, primary roughs, and vegetation associated with recreational areas such as playgrounds, football, baseball, and soccer fields. 
(4)  "Residential landscape irrigation" means the irrigation of landscape associated with any housing unit having sanitary and kitchen facilities designed to accommodate one or more residents, including multiple housing units and mobile homes. 
(5)  "Nonresidential landscape irrigation" means the irrigation of landscape not included within the definition of residential landscape irrigation, such as landscape in public, commercial and/or industrial property, including commercial or transient housing units, hotel and motel units, and public medians and rights-of-way. 
(c)  Landscape irrigation schedules. 
(1)  When Daylight Savings Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
a.  Residential landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or no address may occur only on Wednesday and Saturday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
b.  Residential landscape irrigation at even numbered addresses may occur only on Thursday and Sunday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
c.  Nonresidential landscape irrigation may occur only on Tuesday and Friday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
d.  No more than three-quarters-inch of water may be applied per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs, and in no event shall irrigation occur for more than one (1) hour per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs. 
(2)  When Eastern Standard Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
a.  Residential landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or no address may occur only on Saturday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
b.  Residential landscape irrigation at even numbered addresses may occur only on Sunday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
c.  Nonresidential landscape irrigation may occur only on Tuesday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
d.  No more than three-quarters-inch of water may be applied per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs, and in no event shall irrigation occur for more than one (1) hour per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs. 
(3)  All landscape irrigation shall be limited in amount to only that necessary to meet landscape needs. 
(d)  Exceptions to the landscape irrigation schedules. Landscape irrigation shall be subject to the following irrigation schedule exceptions: 
(1)  Irrigation using a micro-spray, micro-jet, drip or bubbler irrigation system is allowed anytime. 
(2)  Irrigation of new landscape is allowed at any time of day on any day for the initial thirty (30) days and every other day for the next thirty (30) days for a total of one (1) sixty-day period, provided that the irrigation is limited to the minimum amount necessary for landscape establishment. 
(3)  Watering in of chemicals, including insecticides, pesticides, fertilizers, fungicides, and herbicides, when required by law, the manufacturer, or best management practices, is allowed at any time of day on any day within twenty-four (24) hours of application. Watering in of chemicals shall not exceed one-quarter-inch of water per application except as otherwise required by law, the manufacturer, or best management practices. 
(4)  Irrigation systems may be operated at any time of day on any day for maintenance and repair purposes not to exceed twenty (20) minutes per hour per zone. 
(5)  Irrigation using a hand-held hose equipped with an automatic shut-off nozzle is allowed at any time of day on any day. 
(6)  Discharge of water from a water-to-air air-conditioning unit or other water-dependent cooling system is not limited. 
(7)  The use of water from a reclaimed water system is allowed anytime. For the purpose of this section, a reclaimed water system includes systems in which the primary source is reclaimed water, which may or may not be supplemented from another source during peak demand periods. 
(8)  The use of recycled water from wet detention treatment ponds for irrigation is allowed anytime provided the ponds are not augmented from any ground or off-site surface water, or public supply sources. 
(e)  Additional requirement. Any person who irrigates landscape with an automatic lawn sprinkler system installed after May 1, 1991, shall install, maintain and operate a rain sensor device or switch that overrides the irrigation system when adequate rainfall has occurred. 
(f)  Variance from specific day of the week limitations. A variance from the specific landscape irrigation days or day set forth in subsection (c) may be granted if strict application of the scheduled days or day would lead to unreasonable or unfair results in particular instances, provided that the applicant demonstrates with particularity that compliance with the scheduled days or day will result in a substantial economic, health or other hardship on the applicant requesting the variance or those served by the applicant. Where a contiguous property is divided into different zones, a variance may be granted so that each zone may be irrigated on different days or day than other zones of the property. However, in no event shall a variance allow a single zone to be irrigated more than two (2) days per week during Daylight Savings Time or more than one (1) day per week during Eastern Standard Time. 
(g)  Inspection, compliance correction, and penalties. The city manager or his/her designated representative is authorized to enforce the provisions of this regulation. 
(1)  Inspections. A city authorized representative, with or without notice, upon proper identification may enter and inspect all properties, sites and facilities for activities as they relate to proper water conservation for landscape irrigation and compliance with this regulation. Inspection procedures are not limited to, but may include, photographing and or video taping infrastructure and activities. 
(2)  Compliance correction. Upon verbal or written notice, the resident, user, and/or the owner of the property, site or facility shall correct any compliance violation. Correction shall be at a time interval to be determined by the city. 
(3)  Penalties. Upon the determination of violation of this regulation, all fines and penalties are applicable, which are provided in Article VI, Code Enforcement, of Chapter 2, Administration, of this Code. 
(h)  Policies and procedures. The city manager may develop programs, policies, and procedures to administer this regulation. The city council may establish fees where applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Secs. 32-36-32-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 

Sec. 32-41. - General provisions. 
(a)  Purpose and policy. This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for direct and indirect contributors into the wastewater collection and treatment system for the City of Jacksonville Beach and enables the city to comply with all applicable State and Federal Laws required by the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR Part 403) or as otherwise provided by Federal Law. The objectives of this chapter are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will interfere with the operation of the system or contaminate the resulting sludge; 
(2)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system; 
(3)  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludge from the system; and 
(4)  To provide for equitable distribution of the cost of the municipal wastewater system. 
    This section provides for the regulation of direct and indirect contributors to the municipal wastewater system through the issuance of permits to certain nondomestic users and through enforcement activities, requires user reporting, assumes that existing customer's capacity will not be pre-empted, and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
    This section shall apply to the City of Jacksonville Beach and to persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's public owned treatment works (POTW). Except as otherwise provided herein, the director of public works shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article of this chapter. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  "Act" or "the Act" shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
(2)  "Approval authority" shall mean the director in an NPDES state with an approved state pretreatment program and the administrator of the EPA in a non-NPDES state or NPDES state without an approved state pretreatment program. 
(3)  "Authorized representative of industrial user." An authorized representative of an industrial user may be: (1) a principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president, if the industrial user is a corporation; (2) a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; (3) an authorized representative of the individual designated above if the representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates. 
(4)  "Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)" shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
(5)  "Building drain" shall mean that part of the piping of a building which collects wastewater inside the walls of the building and conveys it to outside the building wall. 
(6)  "Building sewer" shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
(7)  "Categorical standards" shall mean the National Categorical Pretreatment Standards or Pretreatment Standard. 
(8)  "City" shall mean the City of Jacksonville Beach, or where appropriate the term shall also mean the city manager, to include the manager's assigned representative(s), who is responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter of the City Code of Ordinances. 
(9)  "City council" shall mean the elected officials of the City of Jacksonville Beach. 
(10)  "Cooling water" shall mean the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
(11)  "Control authority." The term "control authority" shall refer to the "approval authority," defined above; or the director of public works if the city has an approved pretreatment program under the provisions of 40 CFR 403.11. 
(12)  "Customer" shall mean every person who is responsible for contracting (expressly or implicitly) with the city in obtaining, having or using sewer connections with, or sewer taps to, the city's sewer system and in obtaining, having, or using water and other related services furnished by the city for the purpose of disposing of wastewater and sewage through the city's sewer system. The terms shall include the occupants of each unit of a multiple-family dwelling unit building as a separate and distinct customer. 
(13)  "Direct" discharge shall mean the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the State of Florida. 
(14)  "Director of public works" or "director" shall mean the person designated by the city manager to administer activities related to water, wastewater, roads, drainage, sanitation, etc. The term also includes the director's assigned representative(s). 
(15)  "Easement" shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
(16)  "Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)" shall mean the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate the term may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other authorized official of that agency. 
(17)  "Floatable fat, oils and/or grease" shall mean fat, oils and/or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat, oils and/or grease if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
(18)  "Flush toilet" shall mean the common sanitary flush commode in general use for the disposal of human excrement. 
(19)  "Garbage" shall mean the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
(20)  "Grab sample" shall mean a sample which is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time. 
(21)  "Health officer" shall mean the Duval County Environmental Health Director. 
(22)  "Holding tank waste" shall mean any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump trucks. 
(23)  "Indirect discharge" shall mean the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under Section 307(b) or (c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1317), into the POTW (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
(24)  "Industrial user" shall mean a source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1342). 
(25)  "Industrial wastes" shall mean the wastewater from industrial processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
(26)  "Infiltration/inflow" shall mean groundwater and surface water which leaks into the sewers through cracked pipes, joints, manholes or other openings. 
(27)  "Interference" shall mean the inhibition or disruption of the POTW treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit. The term includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the POTW in accordance with Section 405 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1345) or any criteria, guidelines, or regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Title IV of SWDA) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the POTW. 
(28)  "National Categorical Pretreatment Standard" or "pretreatment standard" shall mean any regulation containing pollutant discharge limitations promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1317) which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
(29)  "National Prohibitive Discharge Standard" or "prohibitive discharge" standard shall mean any regulation developed under the authority of Section 307(b) of the Act (40 CFR, Section 403.5). 
(30)  "Natural outlet" shall mean any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body or surface of groundwater. 
(31)  "New source" shall mean any source, the construction of which is commenced after the publication of proposed regulations prescribing a Section 307(c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1317) Categorical Pretreatment Standard which will be applicable to the source, if the standard is promulgated within one hundred twenty (120) days of proposal in the Federal Register. Where the standard is promulgated later than one hundred twenty (120) days after proposal, a new source means any source, the construction of which is commenced after the date of promulgation of the standard. 
(32)  "National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit" shall mean a permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1342). 
(33)  "Person" shall mean any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, the singular shall include the plural where indicated by the context. 
(34)  "pH" shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in grams per liter of solution. 
(35)  "Pit privy" shall mean a shored, vertical pit in the earth completely covered with a fly-tight slab on which is securely located a fly-tight riser covered with hinged fly-tight seat and lid. 
(36)  "Pollution" shall mean the manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological, and radiological integrity of water. 
(37)  "Pollutant" shall mean any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
(38)  "Pretreatment" or "treatment" shall mean the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state before or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing the pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or by process changes or other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR Part 403.6(d). 
(39)  "Pretreatment requirements" shall mean any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, other than a National Pretreatment Standard imposed on an industrial user. 
(40)  "Properly shredded garbage" shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to the degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension. 
(41)  "Public owned treatment works (POTW)" shall mean a treatment works as defined by Section 212 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1292) which is owned in this instance by the city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. For the purposes of this chapter, "POTW" shall also include any sewers that convey wastewaters to the POTW from persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's POTW. 
(42)  "POTW treatment plant" shall mean that portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment to wastewater. 
(43)  "Public sewer" shall mean a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
(44)  "Sanitary sewer" shall mean a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
(45)  "Septic tank" shall mean a subsurface impervious tank designed to temporarily retain sewage or similar waterborne wastes together with: 
a.  A sewer line constructed with solid pipe, with the joints sealed, connecting the impervious tank with a plumbing stub out; and 
b.  A subsurface system of trenches, piping and other materials constructed to drain the clarified discharge from the tank and distribute it underground to be absorbed or filtered. 
(46)  "Sewage" shall mean the spent water of a community. The equivalent term is "wastewater" (see definition below). 
(47)  "Sewer" shall mean a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater. 
(48)  "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
(49)  "Significant industrial user" shall mean any industrial user of the city's wastewater disposal system who (1) has a discharge flow of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons or more per average work day, or (2) has a flow greater than five (5) percent of the flow in the city's wastewater treatment system, or (3) has in his wastes toxic pollutants as defined pursuant to Section 307 of the Act of Florida Statutes and rules or (4) is found by the city, (state control agency) or the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the wastewater treatment system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality, or air emissions generated by the system. 
(50)  "Slug" shall mean any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentrations of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater facilities. 
(51)  "State" shall mean the State of Florida. 
(52)  "Standard Industrial Classification (SIC)" shall mean a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget, 1972, as amended. 
(53)  "Storm drain" sometimes termed storm sewer, it shall mean a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water, or unpolluted water from any source. 
(54)  "Stormwater" shall mean any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
(55)  "Suspended solids" shall mean total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as non-filterable residue. 
(56)  "Toxic pollutant" shall mean any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the provision of Section 307(a)(1) of the Act or other Acts. 
(57)  "Unpolluted water" shall mean water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
(58)  "User" shall mean any person who contributes causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into city POTW. 
(59)  "Wastewater" shall mean the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
(60)  "Wastewater facilities" shall mean the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
(61)  "Waters of the state" shall mean all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through, or border upon the state or any portion. 
(62)  "Watercourse" shall mean a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(63)  "Chemical oxygen demand (COD)" shall mean a measure of oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidant. 
(64)  "Industrial waste surcharge" shall mean the charge made in excess of the sewer service charge for all wastewater over and above normal wastewater. 
(65)  "Normal wastewater" shall mean wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers in which the average concentration of total suspended solids and BOD is not more than two hundred fifty (250) mg/l, total phosphorus is not more than fifteen (15) mg/l, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than thirty (30) mg/l; and total flow is not more than twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day. 
(c)  Abbreviations. The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BOD - Biochemical oxygen demand CFR - Code of Federal Regulations COD - Chemical oxygen demand EPA - Environmental Protection Agency FDEP - Florida Department of Environmental Protection l - Liter mg - Milligrams mg/l - Milligrams per liter NPDES - National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System POTW - Publicly owned treatment works SIC - Standard Industrial Classification SWDA - Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq. TSS - Total suspended solids USC - United States Code  
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-42. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  All premises shall be provided, by its owner, with at least one toilet. All toilets shall be kept clean and in a sanitary working condition. 
(b)  No person shall dispose of human excrement except in a toilet. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this chapter. 
(d)  Except as provided below, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(e)  The owner(s) of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the city jurisdiction and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the city, is required at the owner(s) expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein. 
(f)  All sinks, dishwashing machines, lavatories, basins, shower baths, bathtubs, laundry tubs, washing machines, and similar plumbing fixtures or appliances shall be connected to the public sewer; provided, that where no sewer is available, septic tanks or other private subsurface disposal facilities, approved by the health officer and the city may be used. 
(g)  Customer shall be notified when sewer is available. 
(1)  Sewage shall be considered available to an existing single-family dwelling when the dwelling can be connected by gravity flow to a line in any public right-of-way or easement which passes the property at any point. 
(2)  Sewage shall be considered available to any new single-family dwelling when the dwelling can be connected by the installation of one hundred (100) linear feet of gravity flow line from the nearest point of the property. 
(h)  Sewer charges shall be in effect upon notification of the availability of sewer service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-43. - Private wastewater disposal. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 32-42, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. No person shall construct a septic tank or other wastewater disposal facility without prior approval from the director of public works' office. The availability of sewer is defined in section 32-42 of this chapter. 
(b)  Septic tanks shall be constructed, repaired, altered, enlarged and maintained in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the health officer. 
(c)  No person shall construct, repair, alter or enlarge any septic tank unless he receives approval by the director of public works and shall hold a valid permit for the work issued by the health officer and a permit issued from the city. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all regulations of the Department of Environmental Protection of the State of Florida. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  No septic tank or other subsurface disposal facility shall be installed where a public sewer is accessible to the premises involved. 
(f)  When a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within three hundred sixty-five (365) days after notice. Any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall then be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable materials. 
(g)  The owner(s) shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(h)  Every flush toilet shall be connected to a public sewer where available or to a septic tank. Flush toilets shall be provided at all times with sufficient running water under pressure to flush the toilet clean after each use. 
(i)  No pit privy shall be installed. 
(j)  Discharge of septic tanks into sewer system. 
(1)  Restricted. It shall be unlawful to empty, dump, throw or otherwise discharge, into any manhole, catch basin or other opening, into the city sewer system, or any system connected with and discharging into the sewer system, the contents of any septic tank, sludge, sewage or other similar matter or material, except as provided as follows in the Permits subsection. 
(2)  Permits. The director of public works is authorized to grant permits to discharge the contents of septic tanks (from domestic sources only) at locations specified by him and under his supervision. These permits may be revoked at any time, if in the determination of the director of public works, continued dumping of this matter into the sewers will be injurious to the sewer system or treatment processes. 
(3)  Charges. A charge shall be made for the privilege of dumping contents of septic tanks, as provided in separate rules. A record shall be kept of these dumpings and statements shall be payable within ten (10) days after rendition. Failure to pay the charges within the ten-day period shall be cause for revoking the permit. 
(k)  Any premises that has a septic tank, privy or any other private sewage, industrial waste, or liquid waste disposal system that does not function in a sanitary manner shall be corrected within thirty (30) days from the receipt of notification from the health officer that the system is not functioning in a sanitary manner, and order that the system be corrected. 
(l)  Premises with private water systems shall not be connected with the public sewerage system unless approved by city council. 
(m)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Ord. No. 2012-8016, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 32-44. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance without first obtaining a written permit from the director of public works. 
(b)  The owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the determination of the director of public works. A permit and inspection fee as specified elsewhere shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the front of the building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from this type of single connection. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the director of public works, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(f)  The size, slope, alignment, materials or construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in construction shall all conform to the requirements of the city's building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations. In amplification or absence of city code provisions, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(g)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage that is carried by the building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(h)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless the connection is approved for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. 
(i)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the director of public works when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the director of public works or his representative. 
(j)  All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights in compliance with all OSHA requirements so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(k)  The city council will define the availability of sewers and costs associated with sewer permits or construction. 
(l)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the city's building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. The connections shall be made gas-tight and watertight and verified by proper testing.
